transformed_texts:
So, I think the Catholic Church needs to, like, update its views a bit. You know, people are saying the Church is losing followers, and I think it might be because they're not super accepting of things like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. The Church has strong opinions about these things, which is fine, but they seem a little stuck in the past to me. If they were more open to new ideas, maybe they wouldn't worry so much about losing people.

I've heard some folks are starting to turn on the Church because of how they see these issues. People don't always agree with them anymore. For example, if you believe in abortion rights, you might not feel comfortable in a Church that says it's completely wrong. 

Same goes for gay marriage or other things like that. If you support those things, you might not want to be in a group that doesn't.

Personally, I don't see why they can't have female priests or allow priests to get married. But I'm not sure if that would have stopped the recent scandals. It's hard to say for sure. 

I mean, even if priests were allowed to marry, would that have changed things? It's tough to know. But I think it's fair for priests to have both a job and a family life, just like everyone else.

Okay, so, like, about gay marriage, I'm totally cool with it. I don't think it's something people choose, you know? It's just how they are.  Like, I was born straight, and someone else might be born gay - it's just how life goes. It doesn't feel like a choice anyone makes, so it wouldn't be fair to judge them for it.  

It feels wrong to say that a man and a woman can marry but two people of the same sex can't.  I haven't really thought about it too much, but it just seems like it shouldn't be that way.

Honestly, I don't think the government should even be involved. It's not like it's a security issue, or a big moral thing. It's just people wanting to be happy. It's not like the government should be telling people who they can and can't love.  It's their lives, you know?

Okay, so I think gay marriage should totally be legal. I mean, seriously, what's the big deal? 

Some people freak out about gay couples messing up families, but it's just not the same thing. It's like comparing apples and oranges, you know? They're both fruit, but totally different.

Plus, there's a bunch of rights that come with marriage, like taxes and healthcare. If you're in a gay couple, your partner can't be with you in the hospital or make medical decisions for you if you're sick. It's crazy! How can they not be considered family if they're spending their lives together?

And studies show that gay couples have just as much success in their relationships as straight couples. They have the same issues, the same joys, the same stuff. It's just love, right?

Honestly, all the fuss about gay marriage being a religious issue doesn't make sense. They're not asking for a church wedding, just a legal document from the government.  It's like saying a civil union is okay, but a marriage isn't. That's just messed up.

It's like segregation all over again, separate but unequal.  They're the same relationship, just with different genders.

People worry about adoption and how kids will turn out, but that's just fear-mongering. Gay couples can be just as good parents as straight couples. It's about love and support, not who you're attracted to.

The government should totally step in and make gay marriage legal in every state. It's not a political issue, it's a human rights issue. We need to be accepting of everyone, regardless of who they love.

Okay, so, picture this: I work at a hospital pharmacy during the summer. It makes you think, right? Just 'cause something's illegal doesn't mean it's not good for you.  Like, should the public have access to it? Absolutely not. But for medicine?  Totally. Because, honestly, being illegal doesn't mean something's bad. It just means it's, well, illegal.  Think about it, there are a ton of drugs pharmacies use that are illegal, like oxycodone, Vicodin, Percocet—those kinds of things. They're serious drugs, but they're helpful.  So, why should we be afraid of marijuana just because of the stigma?  We should look at its benefits, you know?

It's not like alcohol, though.  Alcohol can get messed up too, but with marijuana, it's more about how you use it.  It's tricky, but maybe we should ease into making it legal, not just throw it open.  We need to get rid of the bad rap first, then people might use it responsibly.  People think marijuana is super bad because it's illegal, but it's not like heroin or anything. It's not that scary. If we change how we see it, people might use it responsibly, especially for medicine.

You know, I think the church has really changed with the times. It's not as strict as it used to be. When I was younger, every Sunday I'd go to church, all dressed up in a cute dress, matching shoes and purse. That was the routine. I went to a private school, so I'd see all my friends there on weekends. But now, things are different. They have this teen mass, which is only thirty minutes long!  People dress way more casual, especially in the summer. You'll see people in their beach clothes, straight from the sand!  Families run in late, it's a lot more relaxed. Even at the morning masses, where I used to always dress up, people are wearing jeans and khakis these days.  It's definitely more casual overall.  That's the biggest change I've noticed. 



As for all the stuff about priests and the accusations, I don't think allowing priests to get married or have female priests would have stopped those things from happening.  Married men can still be pedophiles, you know? It's about the person, not their marital status.  Plus, becoming a priest is a choice. There are other religions where priests can be married, like that Reverend guy on that show "Seventh Heaven." If someone really wants to practice their faith and also be married, maybe they should look into a different religion.



I think pedophilia is probably more about genetics. It's not like people choose to be that way. You can't just change that by getting married. It might come out eventually. I don't think the church could have prevented this from happening.  If they knew about it and covered it up, that's terrible, but I don't think they always knew.

(laughs)

Honestly, at first, I was okay with the idea, but everyone was still so shaken up after 9/11.  I think we went into Iraq for the wrong reasons. There were lots of excuses used to justify it.  I think the Bush administration linked the Iraq War to Osama Bin Laden and 9/11 right away, saying Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction.  We now know that was all a lie, and it really bothers me.

The whole Iraq War just makes my blood boil. It feels like the Bush administration straight up lied to the American people and still hasn't admitted it.

Even Colin Powell, after that big speech he gave at the UN, now says he wasn't really convinced by the evidence even when he was presenting it! To me, that's just wrong.  It feels like a serious abuse of power, something that should be punishable by law.  I think the Bush administration has totally disregarded the Constitution and tried to weaken it ever since 9/11. They probably came into office wanting to go to war.

There was even that Treasury Secretary - I can't remember his name - who said in his book (after he was probably pushed out) that the younger Bush wanted revenge against Saddam Hussein because of what happened to his dad.  And I think he also wanted to control Iraq's oil resources, which is just a sneaky way to do things.

This whole thing has gone on for too long.  Pulling out right now would probably cause problems because Iraq could collapse into civil war and even more people would die.

The UN and the US are trying to get other countries like Syria and Saudi Arabia to help stabilize the situation, but I'm not sure that's a good idea either. It could create even more problems in the long run because it would raise questions about Iraq's sovereignty.

Right now, the government seems to be falling apart. The Parliament isn't working well, and the Prime Minister doesn't really seem to be in control. Even that guy, Muqtada al-Sadr, who we were fighting not too long ago, now has a lot of seats in Parliament. We're still dealing with all these different groups fighting for power, and the political situation is really tense. 

(laughs)

There's a lot more I could say, but it's probably not appropriate for polite company.

Mmm, this is a tough one.  The whole Iraq war thing... it just feels pointless, you know? I mean, it wasn't even a real declared war.  It feels like we just went in there to get back at Iraq after 9/11. I'm not really into keeping up with all the details, but it seems like we're trying to build democracy over there, kind of like making Iraq another America. And maybe we want their oil too.  But honestly, it's just making everyone upset. 

Staying there forever to build democracy is a long shot. Democracy doesn't just appear overnight. Plus, if we leave, they'll probably be mad because they'll have to start over.  It's a real mess.

I honestly don't know much about this topic.  It's so complicated.

Maybe the war should keep going, but not really as a "war". It feels like we're just showing off our military power, like saying "Look how strong we are!" But maybe we shouldn't have called it a war in the first place, because it wasn't officially declared by Congress.

I do think we should try to help them, but it's also a waste of resources. It's making Bush look bad, like another Vietnam.

And it's hard to think about the families who have loved ones in Iraq. You want them to come home safe, but it feels like we're hurting the Iraqi people too.  They're dealing with violence and lost education because of the conflict.

But trying to change their culture to be more like ours might make things worse. It could make them hate us even more.

I just don't know what the answer is. This whole thing is going to drag on for years and years.

Hmm... this whole thing about making it legal, I just don't feel right about it. It should be up to the churches, you know?  The constitution even says separation of church and state, it's clear as day. Trying to force anything on this, trying to control it, that's going against what's already written.  

Those pushing to make it illegal, I think they're just picking one church's belief over another.  Most Catholics and Christians are against it, except for maybe in some places like Boston. But it shouldn't be up to the government to decide what churches can and can't do. 

Separation of church and state is a big deal, it's what allows for religious freedom in this country. Even thinking about an amendment, that's wrong. It would go against what's already there and be one of the few amendments that restricts people instead of the government.

I don't think the federal government should be involved at all.  I don't know why this guy is pushing for an amendment unless it's just because of his own Catholic beliefs. It seems like he's choosing one religion over others. It should be up to the churches to decide, not the president or anyone in government. There isn't a good reason to ban it, it's just personal opinion.

Okay, so let's talk about the war in Iraq.  Honestly, I don't think the government was completely upfront with the American people about why we went to war.  Before invading Iraq, they tried to connect it to the September 11th terrorist attacks, even though there wasn't a strong link. They used the emotions from 9/11 to push people into supporting the invasion, which started in 2003.

Personally, I'm against war, especially preemptive strikes.  This war in Iraq feels a lot like the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes.  So many American soldiers have died, and it's heartbreaking.  The US took down the Iraqi government, but they weren't ready for the chaos and power vacuum that followed.

They tried to install a democracy, similar to what they did in Vietnam, trying to push out communism and promote democracy.  But the US government should have known it would be a long and difficult fight, not a quick victory.  

There will always be resistance, no matter how many people want the US there.  You're fighting citizens, not an army, which makes it really hard.  

I think the government should have planned better.  They weren't prepared for what would happen after removing the Iraqi government. We're still there in 2006, with American troops dying, and they're still trying to train Iraqi forces. It's a long process.

I feel like the government tried to mislead the American people, making it seem like a short, successful mission.  Building a new government takes time, as we saw in our own country.  

It's a tough decision because we've been there so long. How can we just leave now, after removing their government and way of life?  But how many more American lives are we willing to sacrifice for a democratic Iraq?

And let's be real, isn't it all about oil?  We're getting our oil from there.  The whole thing feels like it's about control and resources.  Remember, they said Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but they never found any.  Yet, we haven't done anything about North Korea, even though they have WMDs.

I just hope for peace in Iraq soon, but I'm not optimistic.

Okay, so like, I'm totally for gay marriage, always have been. It's just a personal thing, you know? And it's becoming more and more clear that it's actually biological, not just something people choose. It feels wrong to take away someone's rights because of something they can't control.  It's just not fair. I've always been on the side of equality for everyone.

It's not the government's business, either. This is about personal choices, families, real lives. Think about it - there are gay couples in my neighborhood who are as loving and normal as any other family, even if they can't legally get married. They walk their dogs, they hang out, just like everyone else. It's ridiculous that the government tries to dictate who can and can't get married.

Plus, I've read a lot about how being gay might actually be something in your genes or brain chemistry. It's not a choice, like deciding to play a sport. It's just who you are. 

The whole thing feels so unfair. Straight couples can get married secretly if they want, no big deal. But if two people who love each other want to get married, it's like a national scandal. It should be a private matter, not something that everyone's obsessed with.

Look, when you put something online, it's like shouting it from the rooftops. Everyone can see it!  As an RA, I've had to deal with this before.  

Whatever you post online can change how people see you. If you're talking about causing trouble or violence, someone's going to take notice. You can't just put that out there for the world to see. The internet is a public space.

If your friend on Myspace gets a bulletin about something you posted, it's not just them who knows. Someone probably told the school, and they have to act. They can't ignore it, because what if something bad happens? They might have been able to prevent it.

But, it's tough to know what's serious and what's just messing around. Like, maybe it was a school project gone wrong, or maybe it was something really serious. 

In one case, someone overheard a conversation at school and reported it. When they looked into it, they found some concerning things on the person's Facebook page. It was stuff that might have been a joke, but in the context of the situation, it was taken seriously.

The thing is, when you put stuff online, you're basically giving up any expectation of privacy. If you don't want it seen, don't post it. You can't control what people think or how they interpret it. 

I don't think teachers should be friends with their students on social media and snooping through their profiles. But if something is brought to their attention, it's hard to say it's an invasion of privacy if the person themselves shared it publicly. They have a responsibility to take threats seriously.

Hmm... this war has just dragged on for way too long. At first, I thought it was for a good reason, you know, to bring democracy to a country that didn't have it.  But now, I'm not so sure. It feels like we're just fighting for the sake of fighting, like we need to prove something to the world. 

And honestly, I think some of the reasons we started it might have been a little shady, maybe linked to old issues between President Bush's father and Saddam Hussein.  If the goal was to give people in that country a fair political system, then that would be a good reason. But if there were personal motives mixed in, that wouldn't be right.

I think we showed our strength in the beginning, those first few months of the war were pretty powerful. But it's been years now, and it just seems to keep going and going.

Look, if our goal was to help people who were being oppressed by a dictator, that's a good thing. But I feel like that original purpose has gotten lost somewhere along the way. Now it feels like we're just stuck in this endless fight, and we need a clear end, a real victory or something.

It's just gone on too long.  At some point, those people have to take responsibility for their own country, right? We've been pouring billions and billions of dollars into this war, money that we could be using for our own problems here at home, like poverty and fixing our schools and healthcare. It's a drain on our resources when the reason for the war has become unclear.

So, I have a question about privacy.  Like, what if someone sees something on Myspace that could be harmful and stops something bad from happening? Is that okay?

I mean, on Myspace, you have to be friends with someone to see their profile, right?  So if you add someone as a friend, aren't you giving them permission to see your stuff?

Anytime you put something online, you should know that lots of people might see it.  If someone found something on Myspace that could have saved a life, wouldn't that be a good thing?

It's tough, though, because you can't have someone watching everyone's profiles all the time.  It would be unfair to single out certain students and look at their profiles just because they seem "bad."

It depends on the situation, I guess.  Was someone looking for something specific, or were they just randomly browsing?

Personally, I'm uncomfortable knowing that there are people out there who can see things about me online. I saw a story on TV about a guy who found a girl's screen name and started talking to her on instant messenger. He got her to meet him in less than a minute!

It makes me nervous because people can learn so much about you from your profiles. They can see your pictures, your interests, your class schedule, even who your friends are.

I try to limit what I share online, but it's hard because I also want to be able to connect with my friends. It's a tricky balance.

I only accept friend requests from people I know, but you never really know who's looking at what.

I heard that some high schools have banned Myspace entirely. That seems a bit extreme to me.  How can they tell students what they can and can't do online?

Hmm, you know,  this Iraq situation is tough. It feels wrong to talk about it, like I'm just jumping on the bandwagon of people saying "I told you so."  But honestly, it's hard to argue against the fact that the war was a bad idea from the start.  Everyone agrees except for the people in charge, who don't want to admit they were wrong.  It's like looking at all these polls – in the US, in Iraq, even worldwide –  most people think it was a mistake.  Even US soldiers there feel it was a bad call and want us out.

It's been a mess from the beginning, and getting out is going to be another mess.  There's no easy solution when it comes to the Middle East.  It's like a clash of cultures,  and our government just doesn't understand. They think they can force democracy on a place where it doesn't belong. Saddam was bad, that's for sure, but invading a country just turns things into a disaster. It's like quicksand. 

I don't know what to say about it. There's no good reason to stay there anymore.  I'm sure they have reasons they think are good, but I haven't heard anything convincing.  If they want to leave gradually, I guess that's okay, but just get us out!  Eighty percent of Iraqis want us gone in a year, and some want us gone now.  They're the ones we're supposedly trying to help, and they're telling us to leave.  Maybe they know best. At least if we ask them and they say yes, we can't be blamed if things go bad.

We might not ever be seen as the good guys in the Middle East, but at least we'd be better off leaving than staying in this mess.

Hmm, yeah, I think gender inequality is still a thing in the U.S.  It's not just about women, though. It kinda depends on the kind of work you do.

Women still face a lot of challenges because of the "glass ceiling." Even though equality is supposed to be a thing, sometimes guys find it hard to work under a woman because of how society has always been.  Women often get all the qualifications for a higher position but don't get promoted because people think women shouldn't be in charge.  

It's the same for guys, though, in different ways. Like, imagine a dad staying home with the kids while his wife works - it's not common. People might judge him for it, thinking a man should be the breadwinner.  But maybe he wants to be with his kids, and it works for their family.

And in fashion,  straight guys don't always get taken seriously. Maybe because people think fashion is "for women" and they don't know how a man could really understand it. It's like they're questioning his knowledge just because of his gender. 

So yeah, I think gender discrimination is still around, but it's different for different people depending on their field.

Changing this stuff is tough because society has set ways of thinking. We've come a long way, but change is slow. But things are getting better.  More women are becoming CEOs, and people are starting to accept it.  More dads are staying home with their kids, and people are getting used to it.  And people in fashion are starting to see that guys can have a good understanding of style too. 

Maybe the key is to show the good qualities of people who are often stereotyped.  If we just keep pushing for change, it will happen.

It's not just about gender either.

There are other kinds of discrimination too, like based on where you're from.  Someone who grew up on a farm might not have the best grammar, but they could be super smart.  If they become a CEO, some people might look down on them because of their accent or the way they speak.

Okay, so basically, they didn't make it legal, they just took it off the criminal list. You know, instead of being a serious crime, it's more like a traffic ticket now. You get a citation, not arrested. I think if someone gets caught, it won't be as bad for things like job interviews.  Usually, a drug charge can really mess you up, but with marijuana, maybe not as much.  Even though it's not a crime anymore, people still worry about the future.  It's expensive to arrest and process people for drugs, and then court costs a lot too.  Lots of places don't want to spend that money, even if it means they could use that money for other things, like schools or helping the elderly. In places like Denver, where people are more open-minded, they probably think it's fine to decriminalize it. They can use that money for better things.  

But we shouldn't just have marijuana everywhere, you know?  It's still kind of a taboo thing.  If it was legal, it might be sold everywhere, and people could be smoking in public.  That would be weird. Plus, alcohol can be pretty bad for you, but marijuana can really mess with your life more, maybe even more than alcohol. It's hard to say because everyone reacts differently to drugs. Some people can handle it, others not so much.

Hmm, I'd say yes to the idea of change in the Catholic Church. You know, a lot of what they do is pretty traditional, like things they've been doing for ages. And that's good, having roots in tradition. But, wouldn't it be nice to be a bit more open to change?  Some Catholics, they feel like they *have* to go to church every week, and there are all these strict rules about how things *should* be done. Sometimes it feels like the Church judges people who don't follow the rules perfectly.  They don't always welcome people who aren't exactly "perfect" Catholics, and they don't really accept other religions either.  

Like, my dad was Episcopalian, and my mom was Catholic, but the Church wouldn't marry them because of his religion. That doesn't seem very accepting of other faiths, does it? We're always taught to love everyone, but it seems kinda hypocritical to say you love people but then not accept them.

It's like the rules say one thing, but how they actually act goes against it.  It's all so old-fashioned, but they just keep clinging on to it. 

  I don't think letting priests get married would solve everything, though.  I mean, I think it would be great if they could, but I don't think it would stop them from, you know, doing bad things. It's a different kind of problem.

People who hurt children probably wouldn't stop just because they're married.  It's not about having a spouse, it's about something much deeper.  They would probably do it anyway.

Hmm... this whole marriage thing is really tough, ya know? I'm still trying to figure out where I stand. It's like walking a tightrope between keeping church and state separate, and figuring out how to define marriage without upsetting anyone. 

It's a real head-scratcher.  Should the government even have a say in what marriage is, especially if it's seen as a religious sacrament?  I mean, we don't get special treatment from the government just because we're baptized, right? So maybe we should just see marriage as a civil union, a simple agreement between two people? 

It's like, two people love each other, they want to be together, that's all that matters. The government shouldn't be getting involved in who they are or how they define their relationship. 

And this whole gay marriage debate...  It just seems so personal. I mean, if two people love each other, why not let them get married?

If each state can agree on something like this, maybe it should become a federal law. But changing the constitution to ban gay marriage? That just feels wrong.  The constitution is for big, important things, not for deciding who can get married. It just doesn't seem like the right way to go about it.

Um, growing up in a Christian home, my views on homosexuality are kinda complicated.  I have lots of gay friends and while I don't necessarily agree with their lifestyle, I think they should have the right to marry. I don't think it's a big national issue, though.  Each state should decide for themselves instead of the president making a rule for the whole country, you know?

Like, some states are more liberal, and they'll probably support gay marriage, right?  If you live in a state that's okay with it, I don't think you should really try to argue against it. You chose to live there. 

Basically, I think everyone, gay or straight, should have the same opportunities. So, let each state decide if they want to legalize it.

I already said it, but I just don't think it's fair for Bush to say the whole country can't have gay marriage. It should be up to the individual states. He doesn't live in every state, so he shouldn't get to decide what they want to do.

Some things should be left up to each state, plus he's leaving office soon anyway. If a different president comes in and wants to lift the ban, it'll just go back and forth. It's better to let each state decide what's right for them. They're the ones who have to live with the consequences.

Okay, so like, Myspace is open to everyone, right? It's like a public bulletin board where you share stuff for people to see. So, if you post something there, you gotta know people will see it, even school officials. Even if they're not looking under the school's name, they can still find it from home.

But you know, if checking Myspace helps prevent a school shooting and keeps students safe, that's a good thing, right? Schools have a responsibility to keep us safe. That's super important.

But, it's different if they're just snooping around to catch kids drinking or smoking. That feels like an invasion of privacy.

It's a tricky situation. It's easier to express yourself in writing, but you gotta be careful what you put out there because everything stays online forever.  

Like, if you post something bad about someone, even in an email, it could come back to bite you later.  

It's just, you know, Myspace is public, so if a student posts something and doesn't expect to get in trouble, that's kinda their own fault.

I mean, school officials have a responsibility to keep us safe, and if checking Myspace helps with that, then I think it's okay.

Okay, so... about this whole war thing... At first, I was totally for it.  Nine Eleven really got to me, you know? I felt like we needed to hit back hard, just like they did here.  But looking back, I think we were all so emotional about it that we didn't really think things through. We went in unprepared, without a plan, and it backfired big time.

Now I'm totally against it. I don't think it's doing anything. Honestly, as long as those people are fighting amongst themselves, they're not going to be causing trouble for us.  It feels like we're just getting in the way.  

Nine Eleven made me kind of numb to what's going on over there. I just don't care about those people anymore. They fight each other constantly and can't seem to solve their own problems.

We went in there totally unprepared. We had no idea what we were facing, and their idea of war is so different from ours. They're just savage, and I don't think they're looking to improve their country. They just want us out. And maybe that's what's best.

I think we were just hyped up, caught up in the emotions of it all. We didn't think about the consequences or how they would react to us trying to change their way of life. It felt like we were just looking for revenge.

President Bush probably felt pressured to declare war on Iraq because people wanted it, and I understand where he was coming from. But I think we could have handled it differently. We should have had a better plan, clearer goals, and more unity.

It feels like we were just acting on anger and emotion, and that's all we created over there. Honestly, I don't think we're the ones to change those people. They're probably always going to be like that.

We've made some progress, but not enough to justify staying there forever. We can't just stay there forever, and I think we're hurting ourselves by trying to.

transformed_texts:
So, I think the Catholic Church needs to, like, update its views a bit. You know, people are saying the Church is losing followers, and I think it might be because they're not super accepting of things like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. The Church has strong opinions about these things, which is fine, but they seem a little stuck in the past to me. If they were more open to new ideas, maybe they wouldn't worry so much about losing people.

I've heard some folks are starting to turn on the Church because of how they see these issues. People don't always agree with them anymore. For example, if you believe in abortion rights, you might not feel comfortable in a Church that says it's completely wrong. 

Same goes for gay marriage or other things like that. If you support those things, you might not want to be in a group that doesn't.

Personally, I don't see why they can't have female priests or allow priests to get married. But I'm not sure if that would have stopped the recent scandals. It's hard to say for sure. 

I mean, even if priests were allowed to marry, would that have changed things? It's tough to know. But I think it's fair for priests to have both a job and a family life, just like everyone else.

Okay, so, like, about gay marriage, I'm totally cool with it. I don't think it's something people choose, you know? It's just how they are.  Like, I was born straight, and someone else might be born gay - it's just how life goes. It doesn't feel like a choice anyone makes, so it wouldn't be fair to judge them for it.  

It feels wrong to say that a man and a woman can marry but two people of the same sex can't.  I haven't really thought about it too much, but it just seems like it shouldn't be that way.

Honestly, I don't think the government should even be involved. It's not like it's a security issue, or a big moral thing. It's just people wanting to be happy. It's not like the government should be telling people who they can and can't love.  It's their lives, you know?

Okay, so I think gay marriage should totally be legal. I mean, seriously, what's the big deal? 

Some people freak out about gay couples messing up families, but it's just not the same thing. It's like comparing apples and oranges, you know? They're both fruit, but totally different.

Plus, there's a bunch of rights that come with marriage, like taxes and healthcare. If you're in a gay couple, your partner can't be with you in the hospital or make medical decisions for you if you're sick. It's crazy! How can they not be considered family if they're spending their lives together?

And studies show that gay couples have just as much success in their relationships as straight couples. They have the same issues, the same joys, the same stuff. It's just love, right?

Honestly, all the fuss about gay marriage being a religious issue doesn't make sense. They're not asking for a church wedding, just a legal document from the government.  It's like saying a civil union is okay, but a marriage isn't. That's just messed up.

It's like segregation all over again, separate but unequal.  They're the same relationship, just with different genders.

People worry about adoption and how kids will turn out, but that's just fear-mongering. Gay couples can be just as good parents as straight couples. It's about love and support, not who you're attracted to.

The government should totally step in and make gay marriage legal in every state. It's not a political issue, it's a human rights issue. We need to be accepting of everyone, regardless of who they love.

Okay, so, picture this: I work at a hospital pharmacy during the summer. It makes you think, right? Just 'cause something's illegal doesn't mean it's not good for you.  Like, should the public have access to it? Absolutely not. But for medicine?  Totally. Because, honestly, being illegal doesn't mean something's bad. It just means it's, well, illegal.  Think about it, there are a ton of drugs pharmacies use that are illegal, like oxycodone, Vicodin, Percocet—those kinds of things. They're serious drugs, but they're helpful.  So, why should we be afraid of marijuana just because of the stigma?  We should look at its benefits, you know?

It's not like alcohol, though.  Alcohol can get messed up too, but with marijuana, it's more about how you use it.  It's tricky, but maybe we should ease into making it legal, not just throw it open.  We need to get rid of the bad rap first, then people might use it responsibly.  People think marijuana is super bad because it's illegal, but it's not like heroin or anything. It's not that scary. If we change how we see it, people might use it responsibly, especially for medicine.

You know, I think the church has really changed with the times. It's not as strict as it used to be. When I was younger, every Sunday I'd go to church, all dressed up in a cute dress, matching shoes and purse. That was the routine. I went to a private school, so I'd see all my friends there on weekends. But now, things are different. They have this teen mass, which is only thirty minutes long!  People dress way more casual, especially in the summer. You'll see people in their beach clothes, straight from the sand!  Families run in late, it's a lot more relaxed. Even at the morning masses, where I used to always dress up, people are wearing jeans and khakis these days.  It's definitely more casual overall.  That's the biggest change I've noticed. 



As for all the stuff about priests and the accusations, I don't think allowing priests to get married or have female priests would have stopped those things from happening.  Married men can still be pedophiles, you know? It's about the person, not their marital status.  Plus, becoming a priest is a choice. There are other religions where priests can be married, like that Reverend guy on that show "Seventh Heaven." If someone really wants to practice their faith and also be married, maybe they should look into a different religion.



I think pedophilia is probably more about genetics. It's not like people choose to be that way. You can't just change that by getting married. It might come out eventually. I don't think the church could have prevented this from happening.  If they knew about it and covered it up, that's terrible, but I don't think they always knew.

(laughs)

Honestly, at first, I was okay with the idea, but everyone was still so shaken up after 9/11.  I think we went into Iraq for the wrong reasons. There were lots of excuses used to justify it.  I think the Bush administration linked the Iraq War to Osama Bin Laden and 9/11 right away, saying Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction.  We now know that was all a lie, and it really bothers me.

The whole Iraq War just makes my blood boil. It feels like the Bush administration straight up lied to the American people and still hasn't admitted it.

Even Colin Powell, after that big speech he gave at the UN, now says he wasn't really convinced by the evidence even when he was presenting it! To me, that's just wrong.  It feels like a serious abuse of power, something that should be punishable by law.  I think the Bush administration has totally disregarded the Constitution and tried to weaken it ever since 9/11. They probably came into office wanting to go to war.

There was even that Treasury Secretary - I can't remember his name - who said in his book (after he was probably pushed out) that the younger Bush wanted revenge against Saddam Hussein because of what happened to his dad.  And I think he also wanted to control Iraq's oil resources, which is just a sneaky way to do things.

This whole thing has gone on for too long.  Pulling out right now would probably cause problems because Iraq could collapse into civil war and even more people would die.

The UN and the US are trying to get other countries like Syria and Saudi Arabia to help stabilize the situation, but I'm not sure that's a good idea either. It could create even more problems in the long run because it would raise questions about Iraq's sovereignty.

Right now, the government seems to be falling apart. The Parliament isn't working well, and the Prime Minister doesn't really seem to be in control. Even that guy, Muqtada al-Sadr, who we were fighting not too long ago, now has a lot of seats in Parliament. We're still dealing with all these different groups fighting for power, and the political situation is really tense. 

(laughs)

There's a lot more I could say, but it's probably not appropriate for polite company.

Mmm, this is a tough one.  The whole Iraq war thing... it just feels pointless, you know? I mean, it wasn't even a real declared war.  It feels like we just went in there to get back at Iraq after 9/11. I'm not really into keeping up with all the details, but it seems like we're trying to build democracy over there, kind of like making Iraq another America. And maybe we want their oil too.  But honestly, it's just making everyone upset. 

Staying there forever to build democracy is a long shot. Democracy doesn't just appear overnight. Plus, if we leave, they'll probably be mad because they'll have to start over.  It's a real mess.

I honestly don't know much about this topic.  It's so complicated.

Maybe the war should keep going, but not really as a "war". It feels like we're just showing off our military power, like saying "Look how strong we are!" But maybe we shouldn't have called it a war in the first place, because it wasn't officially declared by Congress.

I do think we should try to help them, but it's also a waste of resources. It's making Bush look bad, like another Vietnam.

And it's hard to think about the families who have loved ones in Iraq. You want them to come home safe, but it feels like we're hurting the Iraqi people too.  They're dealing with violence and lost education because of the conflict.

But trying to change their culture to be more like ours might make things worse. It could make them hate us even more.

I just don't know what the answer is. This whole thing is going to drag on for years and years.

Hmm... this whole thing about making it legal, I just don't feel right about it. It should be up to the churches, you know?  The constitution even says separation of church and state, it's clear as day. Trying to force anything on this, trying to control it, that's going against what's already written.  

Those pushing to make it illegal, I think they're just picking one church's belief over another.  Most Catholics and Christians are against it, except for maybe in some places like Boston. But it shouldn't be up to the government to decide what churches can and can't do. 

Separation of church and state is a big deal, it's what allows for religious freedom in this country. Even thinking about an amendment, that's wrong. It would go against what's already there and be one of the few amendments that restricts people instead of the government.

I don't think the federal government should be involved at all.  I don't know why this guy is pushing for an amendment unless it's just because of his own Catholic beliefs. It seems like he's choosing one religion over others. It should be up to the churches to decide, not the president or anyone in government. There isn't a good reason to ban it, it's just personal opinion.

Okay, so let's talk about the war in Iraq.  Honestly, I don't think the government was completely upfront with the American people about why we went to war.  Before invading Iraq, they tried to connect it to the September 11th terrorist attacks, even though there wasn't a strong link. They used the emotions from 9/11 to push people into supporting the invasion, which started in 2003.

Personally, I'm against war, especially preemptive strikes.  This war in Iraq feels a lot like the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes.  So many American soldiers have died, and it's heartbreaking.  The US took down the Iraqi government, but they weren't ready for the chaos and power vacuum that followed.

They tried to install a democracy, similar to what they did in Vietnam, trying to push out communism and promote democracy.  But the US government should have known it would be a long and difficult fight, not a quick victory.  

There will always be resistance, no matter how many people want the US there.  You're fighting citizens, not an army, which makes it really hard.  

I think the government should have planned better.  They weren't prepared for what would happen after removing the Iraqi government. We're still there in 2006, with American troops dying, and they're still trying to train Iraqi forces. It's a long process.

I feel like the government tried to mislead the American people, making it seem like a short, successful mission.  Building a new government takes time, as we saw in our own country.  

It's a tough decision because we've been there so long. How can we just leave now, after removing their government and way of life?  But how many more American lives are we willing to sacrifice for a democratic Iraq?

And let's be real, isn't it all about oil?  We're getting our oil from there.  The whole thing feels like it's about control and resources.  Remember, they said Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but they never found any.  Yet, we haven't done anything about North Korea, even though they have WMDs.

I just hope for peace in Iraq soon, but I'm not optimistic.

Okay, so like, I'm totally for gay marriage, always have been. It's just a personal thing, you know? And it's becoming more and more clear that it's actually biological, not just something people choose. It feels wrong to take away someone's rights because of something they can't control.  It's just not fair. I've always been on the side of equality for everyone.

It's not the government's business, either. This is about personal choices, families, real lives. Think about it - there are gay couples in my neighborhood who are as loving and normal as any other family, even if they can't legally get married. They walk their dogs, they hang out, just like everyone else. It's ridiculous that the government tries to dictate who can and can't get married.

Plus, I've read a lot about how being gay might actually be something in your genes or brain chemistry. It's not a choice, like deciding to play a sport. It's just who you are. 

The whole thing feels so unfair. Straight couples can get married secretly if they want, no big deal. But if two people who love each other want to get married, it's like a national scandal. It should be a private matter, not something that everyone's obsessed with.

Look, when you put something online, it's like shouting it from the rooftops. Everyone can see it!  As an RA, I've had to deal with this before.  

Whatever you post online can change how people see you. If you're talking about causing trouble or violence, someone's going to take notice. You can't just put that out there for the world to see. The internet is a public space.

If your friend on Myspace gets a bulletin about something you posted, it's not just them who knows. Someone probably told the school, and they have to act. They can't ignore it, because what if something bad happens? They might have been able to prevent it.

But, it's tough to know what's serious and what's just messing around. Like, maybe it was a school project gone wrong, or maybe it was something really serious. 

In one case, someone overheard a conversation at school and reported it. When they looked into it, they found some concerning things on the person's Facebook page. It was stuff that might have been a joke, but in the context of the situation, it was taken seriously.

The thing is, when you put stuff online, you're basically giving up any expectation of privacy. If you don't want it seen, don't post it. You can't control what people think or how they interpret it. 

I don't think teachers should be friends with their students on social media and snooping through their profiles. But if something is brought to their attention, it's hard to say it's an invasion of privacy if the person themselves shared it publicly. They have a responsibility to take threats seriously.

Hmm... this war has just dragged on for way too long. At first, I thought it was for a good reason, you know, to bring democracy to a country that didn't have it.  But now, I'm not so sure. It feels like we're just fighting for the sake of fighting, like we need to prove something to the world. 

And honestly, I think some of the reasons we started it might have been a little shady, maybe linked to old issues between President Bush's father and Saddam Hussein.  If the goal was to give people in that country a fair political system, then that would be a good reason. But if there were personal motives mixed in, that wouldn't be right.

I think we showed our strength in the beginning, those first few months of the war were pretty powerful. But it's been years now, and it just seems to keep going and going.

Look, if our goal was to help people who were being oppressed by a dictator, that's a good thing. But I feel like that original purpose has gotten lost somewhere along the way. Now it feels like we're just stuck in this endless fight, and we need a clear end, a real victory or something.

It's just gone on too long.  At some point, those people have to take responsibility for their own country, right? We've been pouring billions and billions of dollars into this war, money that we could be using for our own problems here at home, like poverty and fixing our schools and healthcare. It's a drain on our resources when the reason for the war has become unclear.

So, I have a question about privacy.  Like, what if someone sees something on Myspace that could be harmful and stops something bad from happening? Is that okay?

I mean, on Myspace, you have to be friends with someone to see their profile, right?  So if you add someone as a friend, aren't you giving them permission to see your stuff?

Anytime you put something online, you should know that lots of people might see it.  If someone found something on Myspace that could have saved a life, wouldn't that be a good thing?

It's tough, though, because you can't have someone watching everyone's profiles all the time.  It would be unfair to single out certain students and look at their profiles just because they seem "bad."

It depends on the situation, I guess.  Was someone looking for something specific, or were they just randomly browsing?

Personally, I'm uncomfortable knowing that there are people out there who can see things about me online. I saw a story on TV about a guy who found a girl's screen name and started talking to her on instant messenger. He got her to meet him in less than a minute!

It makes me nervous because people can learn so much about you from your profiles. They can see your pictures, your interests, your class schedule, even who your friends are.

I try to limit what I share online, but it's hard because I also want to be able to connect with my friends. It's a tricky balance.

I only accept friend requests from people I know, but you never really know who's looking at what.

I heard that some high schools have banned Myspace entirely. That seems a bit extreme to me.  How can they tell students what they can and can't do online?

Hmm, you know,  this Iraq situation is tough. It feels wrong to talk about it, like I'm just jumping on the bandwagon of people saying "I told you so."  But honestly, it's hard to argue against the fact that the war was a bad idea from the start.  Everyone agrees except for the people in charge, who don't want to admit they were wrong.  It's like looking at all these polls – in the US, in Iraq, even worldwide –  most people think it was a mistake.  Even US soldiers there feel it was a bad call and want us out.

It's been a mess from the beginning, and getting out is going to be another mess.  There's no easy solution when it comes to the Middle East.  It's like a clash of cultures,  and our government just doesn't understand. They think they can force democracy on a place where it doesn't belong. Saddam was bad, that's for sure, but invading a country just turns things into a disaster. It's like quicksand. 

I don't know what to say about it. There's no good reason to stay there anymore.  I'm sure they have reasons they think are good, but I haven't heard anything convincing.  If they want to leave gradually, I guess that's okay, but just get us out!  Eighty percent of Iraqis want us gone in a year, and some want us gone now.  They're the ones we're supposedly trying to help, and they're telling us to leave.  Maybe they know best. At least if we ask them and they say yes, we can't be blamed if things go bad.

We might not ever be seen as the good guys in the Middle East, but at least we'd be better off leaving than staying in this mess.

Hmm, yeah, I think gender inequality is still a thing in the U.S.  It's not just about women, though. It kinda depends on the kind of work you do.

Women still face a lot of challenges because of the "glass ceiling." Even though equality is supposed to be a thing, sometimes guys find it hard to work under a woman because of how society has always been.  Women often get all the qualifications for a higher position but don't get promoted because people think women shouldn't be in charge.  

It's the same for guys, though, in different ways. Like, imagine a dad staying home with the kids while his wife works - it's not common. People might judge him for it, thinking a man should be the breadwinner.  But maybe he wants to be with his kids, and it works for their family.

And in fashion,  straight guys don't always get taken seriously. Maybe because people think fashion is "for women" and they don't know how a man could really understand it. It's like they're questioning his knowledge just because of his gender. 

So yeah, I think gender discrimination is still around, but it's different for different people depending on their field.

Changing this stuff is tough because society has set ways of thinking. We've come a long way, but change is slow. But things are getting better.  More women are becoming CEOs, and people are starting to accept it.  More dads are staying home with their kids, and people are getting used to it.  And people in fashion are starting to see that guys can have a good understanding of style too. 

Maybe the key is to show the good qualities of people who are often stereotyped.  If we just keep pushing for change, it will happen.

It's not just about gender either.

There are other kinds of discrimination too, like based on where you're from.  Someone who grew up on a farm might not have the best grammar, but they could be super smart.  If they become a CEO, some people might look down on them because of their accent or the way they speak.

Okay, so basically, they didn't make it legal, they just took it off the criminal list. You know, instead of being a serious crime, it's more like a traffic ticket now. You get a citation, not arrested. I think if someone gets caught, it won't be as bad for things like job interviews.  Usually, a drug charge can really mess you up, but with marijuana, maybe not as much.  Even though it's not a crime anymore, people still worry about the future.  It's expensive to arrest and process people for drugs, and then court costs a lot too.  Lots of places don't want to spend that money, even if it means they could use that money for other things, like schools or helping the elderly. In places like Denver, where people are more open-minded, they probably think it's fine to decriminalize it. They can use that money for better things.  

But we shouldn't just have marijuana everywhere, you know?  It's still kind of a taboo thing.  If it was legal, it might be sold everywhere, and people could be smoking in public.  That would be weird. Plus, alcohol can be pretty bad for you, but marijuana can really mess with your life more, maybe even more than alcohol. It's hard to say because everyone reacts differently to drugs. Some people can handle it, others not so much.

Hmm, I'd say yes to the idea of change in the Catholic Church. You know, a lot of what they do is pretty traditional, like things they've been doing for ages. And that's good, having roots in tradition. But, wouldn't it be nice to be a bit more open to change?  Some Catholics, they feel like they *have* to go to church every week, and there are all these strict rules about how things *should* be done. Sometimes it feels like the Church judges people who don't follow the rules perfectly.  They don't always welcome people who aren't exactly "perfect" Catholics, and they don't really accept other religions either.  

Like, my dad was Episcopalian, and my mom was Catholic, but the Church wouldn't marry them because of his religion. That doesn't seem very accepting of other faiths, does it? We're always taught to love everyone, but it seems kinda hypocritical to say you love people but then not accept them.

It's like the rules say one thing, but how they actually act goes against it.  It's all so old-fashioned, but they just keep clinging on to it. 

  I don't think letting priests get married would solve everything, though.  I mean, I think it would be great if they could, but I don't think it would stop them from, you know, doing bad things. It's a different kind of problem.

People who hurt children probably wouldn't stop just because they're married.  It's not about having a spouse, it's about something much deeper.  They would probably do it anyway.

Hmm... this whole marriage thing is really tough, ya know? I'm still trying to figure out where I stand. It's like walking a tightrope between keeping church and state separate, and figuring out how to define marriage without upsetting anyone. 

It's a real head-scratcher.  Should the government even have a say in what marriage is, especially if it's seen as a religious sacrament?  I mean, we don't get special treatment from the government just because we're baptized, right? So maybe we should just see marriage as a civil union, a simple agreement between two people? 

It's like, two people love each other, they want to be together, that's all that matters. The government shouldn't be getting involved in who they are or how they define their relationship. 

And this whole gay marriage debate...  It just seems so personal. I mean, if two people love each other, why not let them get married?

If each state can agree on something like this, maybe it should become a federal law. But changing the constitution to ban gay marriage? That just feels wrong.  The constitution is for big, important things, not for deciding who can get married. It just doesn't seem like the right way to go about it.

Um, growing up in a Christian home, my views on homosexuality are kinda complicated.  I have lots of gay friends and while I don't necessarily agree with their lifestyle, I think they should have the right to marry. I don't think it's a big national issue, though.  Each state should decide for themselves instead of the president making a rule for the whole country, you know?

Like, some states are more liberal, and they'll probably support gay marriage, right?  If you live in a state that's okay with it, I don't think you should really try to argue against it. You chose to live there. 

Basically, I think everyone, gay or straight, should have the same opportunities. So, let each state decide if they want to legalize it.

I already said it, but I just don't think it's fair for Bush to say the whole country can't have gay marriage. It should be up to the individual states. He doesn't live in every state, so he shouldn't get to decide what they want to do.

Some things should be left up to each state, plus he's leaving office soon anyway. If a different president comes in and wants to lift the ban, it'll just go back and forth. It's better to let each state decide what's right for them. They're the ones who have to live with the consequences.

Okay, so like, Myspace is open to everyone, right? It's like a public bulletin board where you share stuff for people to see. So, if you post something there, you gotta know people will see it, even school officials. Even if they're not looking under the school's name, they can still find it from home.

But you know, if checking Myspace helps prevent a school shooting and keeps students safe, that's a good thing, right? Schools have a responsibility to keep us safe. That's super important.

But, it's different if they're just snooping around to catch kids drinking or smoking. That feels like an invasion of privacy.

It's a tricky situation. It's easier to express yourself in writing, but you gotta be careful what you put out there because everything stays online forever.  

Like, if you post something bad about someone, even in an email, it could come back to bite you later.  

It's just, you know, Myspace is public, so if a student posts something and doesn't expect to get in trouble, that's kinda their own fault.

I mean, school officials have a responsibility to keep us safe, and if checking Myspace helps with that, then I think it's okay.

Okay, so... about this whole war thing... At first, I was totally for it.  Nine Eleven really got to me, you know? I felt like we needed to hit back hard, just like they did here.  But looking back, I think we were all so emotional about it that we didn't really think things through. We went in unprepared, without a plan, and it backfired big time.

Now I'm totally against it. I don't think it's doing anything. Honestly, as long as those people are fighting amongst themselves, they're not going to be causing trouble for us.  It feels like we're just getting in the way.  

Nine Eleven made me kind of numb to what's going on over there. I just don't care about those people anymore. They fight each other constantly and can't seem to solve their own problems.

We went in there totally unprepared. We had no idea what we were facing, and their idea of war is so different from ours. They're just savage, and I don't think they're looking to improve their country. They just want us out. And maybe that's what's best.

I think we were just hyped up, caught up in the emotions of it all. We didn't think about the consequences or how they would react to us trying to change their way of life. It felt like we were just looking for revenge.

President Bush probably felt pressured to declare war on Iraq because people wanted it, and I understand where he was coming from. But I think we could have handled it differently. We should have had a better plan, clearer goals, and more unity.

It feels like we were just acting on anger and emotion, and that's all we created over there. Honestly, I don't think we're the ones to change those people. They're probably always going to be like that.

We've made some progress, but not enough to justify staying there forever. We can't just stay there forever, and I think we're hurting ourselves by trying to.
